t3.desc: Details about changes from release to release

t16.title: The DITA For Publishers Open Toolkit Plugins

t17.title: Installing the Toolkit Plugins
t17.desc: How to install the DITA for Publishers Toolkit plugins to the Open Toolkit.

t18.title: Setting Up The kindlegen Command-Line Utility
t18.desc: The Amazon-supplied kindlegen utility is required in order to produce final-form Kindle books.

t19.title: Generating EPUBs and Kindle Books from DITA Content
t19.desc: The D4P EPUB and Kindle book generation Open Toolkit plugins enable generation of delivery-ready EPUBs and Kindle books from any conforming DITA content.

t20.title: Generating EPUBs From OxygenXML
t20.desc: You can configure a DITA transformation scenario in OxygenXML to generate EPUBs.

t21.title: Generating Kindle Books From OxygenXML
t21.desc: You can configure a DITA transformation scenario in OxygenXML to generate Kindle books.

t22.title: Using Custom CSS Style Sheets
t22.desc: You can include custom CSS styles sheets in your EPUB just as you can for HTML output generally.
t22.keywords: args.copycss args.css args.csspath args.css.output.dir args.css args.cssroot args.css args.cssroot args.css args.cssroot args.css css.output.dir

t23.title: Creating Cover Graphics and Covers
t23.desc: Some readers and book libraries, such as iBooks, have special conventions for cover graphics.
t23.keywords: topicmeta data epub-cover-graphic covers epub-cover-graphic meta map

t24.title: Creating Arbitrary EPUB OPF Metadata
t24.keywords: data data name name meta @value data content meta args.xsl

t25.title: Implementing Overrides for Common Processing
t25.desc: You can use the same args.xsl parameter as for the XHTML transform to specify a custom top-level transform that includes overrides to the base processing.

t26.title: EPUB and Kindle Transformation Parameters
t26.desc: EPUB-specific parameters for the EPUB transformation type

t27.title: args.css.output.dir Ant parameter
t27.desc:
Specifies the directory to put CSS files into for EPUB and Kindle
    transforms.

t28.title: cover.graphic.file Ant parameter
t28.desc: Specifies the absolute or relative path of the graphic to use as the cover graphic for the EPUB.

t29.title: d4p.max.nav.depth Ant parameter
t29.desc:
Specifies the maximum depth of the navigation table of
    contents.

t30.title: d4p.max.toc.depth Ant parameter
t30.desc:
Specifies the maximum depth of the generated HTML table of
    contents.

t31.title: epub.exclude.auto.rellinks Ant parameter
t31.desc: Turns on exclusion of auto-generated related links (as for normal HTML output)

t32.title: epub.pubid.uri.stub Ant parameter
t32.desc: Specifies the URI prefix stub to use in constructing the full EPUB ID value in the EPUB metadata.

t33.title: epub.temp.dir Ant parameter
t33.desc: Specifies the directory to use for EPUB-specific processing separate from the main Toolkit's temp directory.

t34.title: images.output.dir Ant parameter
t34.desc: Specifies the name of the directory within the EPUB to hold all images.

t35.title: kindlegen.executable Ant parameter
t35.desc: Specifies the name, and if necessary, full path of the kindlegen command-line executable

t36.title: title.only.topic.class.spec Ant parameter
t36.desc: Specifies the @class attribute value to use for title-only topics generated from topicheads.

t37.title: title.only.topic.title.class.spec Ant parameter
t37.desc: Specifies the @class attribute value to use for titles for title-only topics generated from topicheads.

t38.title: topics.output.dir Ant parameter
t38.desc: Specifies the name of the directory within the EPUB to hold all the topics.

t39.title: Map-Driven Processing
t39.desc:
Using and extending the DITA for Publishers map-driven processing
    framework

t40.title: Numbering Things: Collected Data and Enumeration
t40.desc:
How to use the collected enumeration data to number things in
    output.
t40.keywords: bodydiv sectiondiv div enum:enumerables class df:generate-dita-id() enumeration xsl:number

t41.title: Index Generation
t41.desc:
Overview of using the grouped and sorted index entries in the
    collected data to do index generation.
t41.keywords: index-terms:ungrouped index-terms:grouped-and-sorted index-terms:index-term indexterm group-and-sort-index gather-index-terms local:construct-index-group-key() local:construct-index-term-grouping-key()

t42.title: Graphic Map Generation
t42.desc:
The map-driven processing generates an Ant script that copies
    graphics from their source locations to the output location.

t44.title: Understanding the HTML2 Transformations
t44.desc: Guidance on how the HTML2 XSLT transformations are organized and how the processing works.

t45.title: Overall HTML Generation Process Flow
t45.desc: Describes the overall processing flow for the HTML2 transformation

t46.title: Extending and Customizing Enumeration Processing (Numbering)
t46.desc: How to customize and extend the default enumeration processing for topic titles and other numbered things.

t47.title: HTML2 Transformation Parameters
t47.desc: Unique parameters for the HTML2 transformation type

t48.title: html2.file.organization.strategy Ant parameter
t48.desc: Names the output file organization strategy to use for generated files.

t49.title: html2.generate.dynamic.toc Ant parameter
t49.desc: Specifies whether or not to generate a dynamic TOC in the output.

t50.title: html2.generate.frameset Ant parameter
t50.desc: Specifies whether or not to generate an HTML frameset file for the map.

t51.title: html2.generate.static.toc Ant parameter
t51.desc: Specifies whether or not to generate a static TOC in the output.

t52.title: HTML5 Plugin
t52.desc:
The HTML5 transformation type produces HTML5-based output that integrates newer web
    technologies, such as HTML5, CSS3, responsive layouts.

t53.title: Getting Started With the HTML5 Transformation

t55.title: Downloading HTML5 plugin
t55.desc: The html5 plugin is part of the DITA for Publishers set of plugins.

t56.title: Specific installation notes for developpers
t56.desc:
If you want to do development with HTML5 plugin, you will need to
        install the YUI compressor tool.

t57.title: Running the HTML5 Plugin
t57.desc: The HTML5 plugin can run as a regular DITA-OT plugin.

t58.title: Changed Behaviours
t58.desc:
This plugin does not always behaves the same way than others DITA OT
  plugins.

t59.title: License
t59.desc: The DITA for Publishers project is released under the Apache License V2.0

t61.title: Replacing the index.html file
t61.desc:
The HTML5 transformation type does not produce an index.html file by
  default.

t62.title: Multiple columns layout
t62.desc:
The html5plugin can allows you to use the latest CSS multi-columns layout for the browsers that support
        it.

t63.title: CSS grid
t63.desc:
The html5 plugin use the 960 Grid System, which allows technical writters to use the
  attribute outputclass to positions their elements on the grid.

t64.title: Image support
t64.desc: The plugin offers the different options for images.

t65.title: Notes
t65.desc: Notes are output with the aside element except when @importance is set to low or obsolete, which will output a details elements. Details elements should be collapsed by default on new browsers.

t66.title: UI
t66.desc: The plugin allows to interact with jQuery UI to output UI on the content.

t67.title: Accordion
t67.desc: Accordion are alternate navigation used to browse the content more quickly.

t68.title: Cycle
t68.desc: This UI allows to present your image in a slideshow.

t69.title: Developpers
t69.desc: General information to customize the plugin and create a new Theme

t70.title: Creating a customization plugin
t70.desc:
The steps required to create a customization plugin does not differ from others
  DITA-OT plugin.

t71.title: Theme Development
t71.desc:
The theme mechanism is a preprocessing and packaging mechanism which works on CSS and
  javascripts.

t72.title: The Theme cache process
t72.desc: The image belows presents the theme cache process

t73.title: Theme configuration file: principle
t73.desc:
The theme configuration file allows to specify which files you want to concatenate and
  compress into a single file. It also provide the information to the html5 xsl code to generate the
  right link and scripts elements.

t74.title: Let's explore the configuration file
t74.desc: The Theme configuration file is pretty simple to create

t75.title: How to add Internet Explorer conditional css

t76.title: Adding Google analytics tracking code
t76.desc: To add google analytics to your theme, you need add this code to the theme.xml

t78.title: Directory structure
t78.desc: The following describes the structure of the plugin directory.

t79.desc: This properties allows to customize the output.

t80.title: The Word-to-DITA Transformation Framework
t80.desc: The Word-to-DITA (Word2DITA) transformation framework enables the reliable generation of maps and topics form styled Word documents.

t81.title: Getting Started With The Word2DITA Transform
t81.desc: How to set up an Ant task to convert a Word document to DITA using the Open Toolkit

t82.title: Generating DITA from Word Using the Toolkit Plugin
t82.desc: How to use the Word-to-DITA Toolkit Plugin to generate DITA content from Word documents.
t82.keywords: args.input w2d.style-to-tag-map output.dir w2d.clean.output.dir w2d.filter.br w2d.filter.tabs tab w2d.root.output.filename w2d.word2dita.xslt w2d.debug.xslt w2d.media.dir w2d.root.map.name w2d.root.topic.name w2d.submap.name.prefix w2d.include.word.backpointers w2d.include.word.bookmarks w2d.filename.prefix w2d.submap.name.prefix w2d.language w2d.generate.navtitles

t83.title: Setting Up an Ant Script for Running the Word-to-DITA Transform
t83.desc: How to set up an Ant task to run the Word-to-DITA transform against DOCX files.

t84.title: Generating DITA From Within OxygenXML
t84.desc: You can transform Word documents from within OxygenXML without using the Open Toolkit

t85.title: Style to Tag Mapping
t85.desc:
The docx2dita transform is driven by a configuration file, the style-to-tag map. The
    style-to-tag map enables an entirely or almost-entirely configuration-driven transformation of
    styled Word documents into DITA-based XML, specialized or not. Through careful design of Word
    templates it is possible to quickly configure the transformation to produce good XML
    documents.

t87.desc: Tips on figuring out why the Word-to-DITA process isn't working correctly.

t88.desc: A video tutorial on setting up a non-trivial style-to-tag mapping for a typical technical document.

t89.desc: How to customize the XSLT processing to handle special cases

t91.desc: Things you can or should do to make the transformation most effective

t94.title: The DITA-to-InDesign Transformation Framework
t94.desc: The DITA-to-InDesign transformation framework enables the generation of InDesign documents and InCopy articles from DITA maps and topics.

t95.title: Overview of the InDesign and InCopy Products
t95.desc: Adobe InDesign and InCopy are companion products, part of Adobe's Creative Suite set of products. InDesign is a desktop publishing tool widely used in Publishing and where typographic quality and layout sophistication are paramount.

t96.title: Generating InCopy Articles from DITA Topics
t96.desc:
You can directly generate InCopy articles from DITA topics using the
    XSLT transforms in the org.dita4publishers.dita2indesign plugin. You do not
    have to use the Open Toolkit to run the transform.

t97.title: Generating InDesign from DITA Using the Toolkit Plugin
t97.desc: How to use the DITA-to-InDesign Toolkit Plugin to generate inDesign and InCopy documents from DITA content.

t98.title: Configuring the DITA-to-InDesign Transformation
t98.desc: You can generate InCopy articles from single topics or from maps using XSLT.

t99.title: Mapping XML Elements to InDesign Paragraph and Character Styles
t99.desc: You define the mapping of elements to specific character and paragraph styles using simple XSLT templates.
t99.keywords: match class select match priority priority xsl:template foo bar bar bar foo class bar priority bar bar priority

t100.title: Specifying InDesign Grouped Style Names
t100.desc:
InDesign styles may be grouped or ungrouped. Grouped styles require
    a specific syntax.

t101.title: Preparing InDesign Templates for DITA-to-InDesign Use
t101.desc: By taking advantage of InDesign features you can maximize the automation provided by the DITA-to-InDesign framework.

t102.title: Extending the DITA for Publishers Transformations
t102.desc: All the DITA for Publishers transformation plugins can be extended using normal Open Toolkit plugin extension techniques.
t102.keywords: param param d4p.html2.xslt.param param d4p.html2.xslt.param param d4p.html2.xslt.param
